ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned about the extensive history of Yale and its involvement in the student missionary movement, mobilization in WWI & WWII and the repatriation of archaeological artifacts in Peru. I learned a lot about archival research and how to critically analyze primary sources and target collections at Yale's vast resources.
Really really interesting tidbits about Yale's history that changed how I viewed the school I attend.
I learned how Yale influenced global events, how to write a term paper, and how to craft a historical argument.
Learning of how to conduct archival research and write research papers. Additionally I gained an understanding of Yales place and history in the world.
Writing better essays, working with archival evidence

I gained incredible experience working with primary source archives in Sterling Library's Manuscripts and Archives. We would visit the archives almost biweekly and got to both examine and research with fascinating documents there. I greatly developed my skills as a historian in this class.

I thoroughly enjoyed this history seminar. My writing improved and so did my research skills. It was fascinating to learn more about Yale's role in different world events that has helped to shape the university it is today.

It was wonderful to learn about the history of the institution I have been at for years, especially in the context of world power and global affairs. The course covers a good span of Yales history, not all of it but a good portion and its a great opportunity to have conversations in reflections on Yales past- the good and the bad.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The emphasis on archival research is a major strength of the class. Professor Engerman also brought in librarians to our classes in Sterling Memorial Library who also helped us work with archives.

Strengths: Having the opportunity to use Yale's Manuscripts and Archives during class sessions was wonderful. Exposure to the Peabody Museum and  Yale-in-China was fantastic; You learn a lot about Yale's history and mobilization in the world wars. 
Weaknesses: I thought the deadline for the final paper was slightly difficult to meet.

Strengths: special trips to the Yale archives, engaging class conversations, thoughtful and approachable professor
Weaknesses: none that come to mind, though it's inevitable that some weeks' topics will be more/less interesting than other weeks'

Strentgths: some interesting no readings and freedom to write a final paper of our choosing.

Weakness: need more opportunities/workshopping of individuals for bettering their writing.
It's very good, good discussion, good readings, good assignments

The main strength of this course is how much it engages resources of the university, both through archives held by the university and by inviting faculty members of the university to attend class and share their insights with the class about particular historical events they know very well. One example was speaking with Tim White from the Peabody Museum, who had played a huge role in the repatriation of Machu Picchu's artifacts that had been exported to Yale during Hiram Bingham's expeditions there.
Professor Engerman is a strength. He is great at facilitating discussion and choosing readings and the like.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I highly recommend this course to students who are interested in learning more about Yale's collections and manuscripts that can provide amazing primary source information to papers and thesis. I learned about the Yale Daily News Historical Archives and how to critically engage with primary source material from online to museum. You learn about different episodes of Yale that are not covered in the media.
Yes, definitely. You can only take a class like this at Yale, and it's a really cool experience to learn about Yale's history through the archives.
Yes it was a wonderful course  I would recommend it. Dr. Engerman is a great professor.
Yes! A very interesting seminar for any Yale student to take!
Yes for sure!
Yes. It is a remarkable opportunity to learn about Yale and its relation to world history while becoming a more skilled historian.
I would certainly recommend this course to other students. Professor Engerman is a fantastic teacher and facilitates great seminar discussions.
Yes, especially for seniors.
